text: The moment I grabbed a chunk of rubble, my fingers were so stiff I could barely hold it. The storm was too fierce, the Demon King’s black mist heaved like a living thing—and I misjudged the ‘thin point.’
Still, I threw the stone—like hurling my last hope into an abyss.
The stone didn’t crack open an opening. It was simply swallowed by the black mist, without even a sound.
In the next second, the mist snapped upward like an offended beast.
The Demon King didn’t get distracted. It locked on.
Its voice scraped against bone: “You—too—will—come—back—.”
That whisper drilled into my ears and my knees went soft at once. Not fear—something more nauseatingly familiar, as if it had watched me struggle through countless loops.
The black mist suddenly stretched, like a massive claw reaching for me.
I tried to retreat into the shield wall, but the collapsing snow dragged at my feet. I only managed to raise my arm—then, in the next instant, an icy grip had already latched onto my chest.
A broken gasp tore out of my throat. Everything in my vision slowed, as if the world had been twisted tight.
And in that moment, I saw the necklace in Alicia’s hand—she was about to drive it into the core.
Her fingers trembled once. Not fear—fatigue pressing down for a single heartbeat.
I finally understood: if she turned back to save me now, she would lose that half second.
But she turned back anyway.
Alicia whispered, “…Don’t look at me. Close your eyes.”
She couldn’t win on both fronts. She could only choose one.
She pivoted hard, blade sweeping across, forcing the black mist that was reaching for me to split open. The mist shrieked, like torn skin.
That strike saved me. And it stole her chance.
The Demon King’s attention snapped fully back to her. The mist no longer loosened—it recoiled like chains, wrapping tight around her wrists and throat.
The necklace slipped from her fingers and dropped into the snow with a sound so faint it was almost nothing.
But that tiny sound was sharper than any scream.
The Demon King’s claw came down. It wasn’t a slash—it was a ‘reset,’ pressing her back into the rift, snapping the loop back into alignment.
Alicia braced and blocked. Her shoulder guard burst under the pressure; blood seeped along her bracer and dripped onto the snow, turning it dark.
She still stepped forward—forcing herself even closer. That was always her way: trading life for an opening.
But this time, there was no opening.
Black light flashed—like someone had erased a piece of the world. Alicia’s figure was swallowed whole, so cleanly that even her footprints in the snow seemed to be wiped away.
My head rang with a single hollow buzz, like something had been struck and shattered inside me.
The barrier’s blue light began to splinter, breaking into shard after shard like glass. The soldiers’ breathing turned into panicked, ragged gasps.
The core in the Demon King’s chest lit up again. The light was terrifyingly steady, as if proclaiming: the loop continues.
The black mist rolled over me; a cold emptiness flooded my chest, like the world had sentenced me to death. As darkness swallowed my vision, I had only one thought left—I saved myself, and lost her.
